div1.p: Hench offers copies of his yellow fever research material to the Army Medical Museum.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Curator, Army Medical Museum, June 4, 1940
div1.opener:
trip folder.
June 4, 1940
The Curator
Army Medical Museum
Washington, D. C.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
For two years I have been interested in doing some researches on the
work of Walter Reed and the conquest of yellow fever. I was asked by the President
of Washington and Jefferson College to give a talk on this work at the dedication
of their Lazear Memorial Building at Washington and Jefferson College next October.

In the meantime, I have visited personally both Mr. Kissinger and Mr.
Moran, the two army privates who were first to volunteer for the experimental yellow
fever. Their stories have never been published. After considerable trouble and
investigation, I have got their stories in their own words, and I have gone farther
and corresponded with a number of the survivors, two months ago visiting Havana for
about ten days. While there, I visited the supposed site of Camp Lazear and inter-
viewed certain survivors, such as Dr. Albertini, Dr. Finlay's son, Dr. Agramonte's
daughter, and others. As a result, I have collected a considerable amount of inter-
esting material much of which I think you will want copies of, and I shall be de-
lighted to let you have copies of everything I have that you will wish. However,
I am also speaking for your interest and help in my problem.

Undoubtedly, you have some records which I should like to be permitted to
see, and some photographs, copies of which I am most anxious to get--photographs of
Camp Columbia Barracks, Camp Lazear, possibly of Military Hospital No. 1, etc.
I expect to be in Washington from Friday, June 14, until Monday night, June 17, and
plan to visit General Kean, who knows much of this yellow fever work. I hope to be
able to call on you, and discuss this matter further.

I will appreciate it so much if you will drop me a line, addressed to me
at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York, where I will be the week of the American
Medical Association meeting. If you will let me know the time that it will be
most convenient for me to call, I shall appreciate it.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
